title: 108_s3035
content: The Act may be cited as the "Oil Spill Prevention and Liability Act of 2004". It defines the responsible party. Section 1001(32) of the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include regulations for vessels, specifying ownership and operation responsibilities for different types of vessels. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include regulations for vessels, specifying ownership and operation responsibilities for different types of vessels, including hull tank vessels of oil owned or possessed by a person. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include regulations for vessels, specifying ownership and operation responsibilities for different types of vessels, including hull tank vessels of oil owned or possessed by a person. Limits on liability are outlined in Section 3. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to increase liability limits for double-hull tank vessels after December 31, 2004. The amendments include raising the limits to $2,400 for subparagraph (A) and $20,000,000 for clause (i) and $4,000,000 for clause (ii) in paragraph (1). The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to increase liability limits for single-hull tank vessels from January 1, 2005, to December 31, 2006. The limits are set at $2,400 per gross ton or $20,000,000 for vessels over 3,000 gross tons, and $4,000,000 for vessels of 3,000 gross tons or less. From January 1, 2007, to December 31, 2008, liability limits for vessels increased: $4,800 per gross ton or $40,000,000 for vessels over 3,000 gross tons, and $8,000,000 for vessels of 3,000 gross tons or less in 2007; $6,000 per gross ton or $50,000,000 for vessels over 3,000 gross tons, and $6,000,000 for vessels of 3,000 gross tons or less in 2008. From January 1, 2009, to December 31, 2009, liability limits for vessels were set at $7,200 per gross ton for vessels over 3,000 gross tons, and $12,000,000 for vessels of 3,000 gross tons or less. After December 31, 2009, the maximum amount permitted under the Constitution applies. Amendments also increased the liability limits to $1,200 per gross ton and $1,000,000 overall. The liability limits for vessels transporting oil to deepwater ports have been increased from $350,000,000 to $700,000,000. Additionally, the Secretary may establish a limit of liability between $100,000,000 and $700,000,000 for such transportation. The Deepwater Port Act of 1974 has been amended to increase liability limits for vessels transporting oil to deepwater ports from $350,000,000 to $700,000,000. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant agencies, may establish a limit of liability between $100,000,000 and $700,000,000 for such transportation. Additionally, adjustments for inflation have been made to certain sections of the Oil Pollution Act of 1990. SEC. 4. CARRIAGE OF LIQUID BULK DANGEROUS CARGOES. The Ports and Waterways Safety Act is amended to allow port owners to request restrictions on tank vessels posing severe harm risks. Inspection requirements for tank vessels are also updated. Each single-hull tank vessel over 15 years old must undergo an annual inspection according to international regulations. The Commandant of the Coast Guard will conduct a study with the National Academy of Sciences to assess the economic costs of oil spills in the US. A report on the study's results must be submitted to Congress within a year. This Act and its amendments will be effective on January 1, 2005.
